articles.headline: The Center Collapses in France, Leaving Macron Marooned
articles.snippet: Squeezed by the far-right National Rally party and the left, President Emmanuel Macron faces a country that may prove ungovernable.
articles.abstract: Squeezed by the far-right National Rally party and the left, President Emmanuel Macron faces a country that may prove ungovernable.
articles.lead_paragraph: An era has ended in France.

articles.headline: Ruling Further Slows Trump Election Case but Opens Door to Airing of Evidence
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court’s immunity decision directed the trial court to hold hearings on what portions of the indictment can survive — a possible chance for prosecutors to set out their case in public before Election Day.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court’s immunity decision directed the trial court to hold hearings on what portions of the indictment can survive — a possible chance for prosecutors to set out their case in public before Election Day.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on Monday about executive immunity makes it all but certain that former President Donald J. Trump will not stand trial on charges of seeking to overturn the last election before voters decide whether to send him back to the White House in the next one.

articles.headline: Immunity Ruling Escalates Long Rise of Presidential Power
articles.snippet: Beyond Donald J. Trump, the decision adds to the seemingly one-way ratchet of executive authority.
articles.abstract: Beyond Donald J. Trump, the decision adds to the seemingly one-way ratchet of executive authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision to bestow presidents with immunity from prosecution over official actions is an extraordinary expansion of executive power that will reverberate long after Donald J. Trump is gone.

articles.headline: From Courtroom to Downing Street: Keir Starmer Is on the Cusp of Power
articles.snippet: The Labour leader still struggles with the “performative side” of British politics, even as he has pulled his party to the center.
articles.abstract: The Labour leader still struggles with the “performative side” of British politics, even as he has pulled his party to the center.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the U.K. election.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler

articles.headline: A.I. Begins Ushering In an Age of Killer Robots
articles.snippet: Driven by the war with Russia, many Ukrainian companies are working on a major leap forward in the weaponization of consumer technology.
articles.abstract: Driven by the war with Russia, many Ukrainian companies are working on a major leap forward in the weaponization of consumer technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a field on the outskirts of Kyiv, the founders of Vyriy, a Ukrainian drone company, were recently at work on a weapon of the future.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: These Doctors Were Censured. Wisconsin’s Prisons Hired Them Anyway.
articles.snippet: The state’s prison system has faced recent scrutiny for failing to care for inmates.
articles.abstract: The state’s prison system has faced recent scrutiny for failing to care for inmates.
articles.lead_paragraph: While serving time in a Wisconsin prison in 2021, Darnell Price watched a golf-ball-size lump on his thigh grow as large as a football. Mr. Price pressed for a thorough examination, he said, but the prison’s physician, Dr. Joan Hannula, did not order a biopsy.
articles.byline: By Mario Koran and Jamie Kelter Davis

articles.headline: Israeli Generals, Low on Munitions, Want a Truce in Gaza
articles.snippet: Israel’s military leadership wants a cease-fire with Hamas in case a bigger war breaks out in Lebanon, security officials say. It has also concluded that a truce would be the swiftest way to free hostages.
articles.abstract: Israel’s military leadership wants a cease-fire with Hamas in case a bigger war breaks out in Lebanon, security officials say. It has also concluded that a truce would be the swiftest way to free hostages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel’s top generals want to begin a cease-fire in Gaza even if it keeps Hamas in power for the time being, widening a rift between the military and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has opposed a truce that would allow Hamas to survive the war.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Natan Odenheimer

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Politics May Be Pushing Some Buyers Away From Tesla
articles.snippet: The Tesla chief executive’s polarizing statements have alienated some potential customers and may be partly responsible for a recent slump in sales.
articles.abstract: The Tesla chief executive’s polarizing statements have alienated some potential customers and may be partly responsible for a recent slump in sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few auto executives are as closely identified with the companies they manage as Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, is. And probably none are more prolific in broadcasting their political views on social media.

articles.headline: In a Volatile Term, a Fractured Supreme Court Remade America
articles.snippet: Amid signs of dysfunction and disarray, Chief Justice John Roberts reasserted his authority, while the influence of Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel Alito waned.
articles.abstract: Amid signs of dysfunction and disarray, Chief Justice John Roberts reasserted his authority, while the influence of Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel Alito waned.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump had a very good year at the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court ruled that he is substantially immune from prosecution on charges that he tried to subvert the 2020 election. On Friday, the court cast doubt on two of the four charges against him in what remains of that prosecution. And in March, the justices allowed him to seek another term despite a constitutional provision barring insurrectionists from holding office.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Alicia Parlapiano

articles.headline: Student Loan Borrowers Owe $1.6 Trillion. Nearly Half Aren’t Paying.
articles.snippet: Millions of people are overdue on their federal loans or still have them paused — and court rulings keep upending collection efforts.
articles.abstract: Millions of people are overdue on their federal loans or still have them paused — and court rulings keep upending collection efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an unprecedented three-year timeout on federal student loan payments because of the pandemic, millions of borrowers began repaying their debt when billing resumed late last year. But nearly as many have not.
